sourceDesc.bibl: Alfred Sharpe. From Nature to Nature’s God. New Zealand Herald, 24 January 1885, p. 2.

projectDesc.p: Transcribed and encoded as part of Settler Literature and Environmental Change in Australia and New Zealand," Marsden Fund Standard Grant 19-MAU-022 (Te Apārangi Royal Society of New Zealand).

lg.l: Where the breezy moorland stretches,
All with rush and bracken spread;
Where the balmy air-waves quiver
In the sunbeams overhead;
Where the tea-trees, Tea-trees. Mānuka, also known as tea tree, is a low-growing tree that produces small white flowers. lush with blossoms,
White and starry masses show,
Which, when kissed by passing zephyrs,
Flutter down like mimic snow;
Where the sweet clematis Clematis. There are as many as nine indigenous New Zealand species of clematis, a climbing vine. twineth,
With its tufted, feathery mass;
And where wave the plumes and spearlets
Of the toi-toi grass: Toi-toi grass. Toetoe describes several species of giant indigenous tussock grass that produce feathery flower plumes on tall stems.
To sweet Nature’s charms addrest,
There my soul finds blessed rest.
Where primœval forest darkens;
Where the giant kauri Kauri. Kauri trees can grow as tall as forty or fifty metres in height and attain ages of over 1,000 years. towers;
Where the mighty-limbed puriri Puriri. Pūriri trees can grow as tall as twenty metres, and produces bright pink, red, or purple flowers.
Strews the ground with purple flowers;
Where the lordly rata Rata. The northern rātā can grow to over forty metres high, and produces red flowers. showeth
Forth her mass of crimson bloom;
Where the leafy, dark tiriri Tiriri. Likely taraire, a tree found north of Auckland in the North Island, which can grow over twenty metres high.
Spreads a semi-twilight gloom;
Where the towering kahikatea Kahikatea. Kahikatea is the tallest tree species in Aotearoa New Zealand, growing as tall as sixty metres, and typically grows on lowland swampy terrain.
Rises far into the air;
Clad with green taweras, Taweras. Tāwari is a small tree that produces white flowers. and with
Flowering creepers, bright and fair:
To sweet Nature’s charms addrest,
There my soul finds blessed rest.
Where the tawa’s Tawa’s. Tawa is the dominant tree species in many North island lowland forests, growing to a heigh of thirty metres. willowy leafage
Lets the sunlight dance below;
Where the resinous tanekehas Tanekahas. Tānekaha, also known as the celery pine, is a lowland forest tree whose leaves are in fact leaf-like shoots.
Leafy pyramidals show;
Where the drooping-frondaged rimu Rimu. Rimu is a large lowland forest tree with pendulous branches.
Sways its tassels in the breeze,
Which meanders, perfume-laden,
In and out amongst the trees;

Where the matai, Matai. Mataī, or black pine, is a tall lowland forest tree with dark grey bark. and the maire, Maire. There are several species of the Maire tree, including the Black Maire, which was actively logged by settlers in the Auckland area.
Show contrasts of light and shade;
Where totaras, Totaras. Tōtara is a common lowland forest tree with reddish-grey bark. with their bronzings,
Dot in clumps, the forest glade:
To sweet Nature’s charms addrest,
There my soul finds blessed rest.
Where the maiden-hair ferns Maiden-hair ferns. Makaka, or maidenhair fern, is largely restricted to the top half of the North Island. quiver
With the echoes of the air;
Where the multifarious fernlets
Spread a carpet rich and rare;
Where the palm fronds of the nikau Nikau. The nīkau, New Zealand’s only native palm, has closely spaced dark green leaves and can grow to a height of fifteen metres.
Show like emerald in the glade;
Where the feathery punga’s Punga’s. Most likely a reference to ponga, a common species of tree fern also known as the silver fern. frondage
Casts a luminous amber shade;
Where the snake ferns, Snake ferns. The plant species referred to is unclear. orange spotted,
Twine o’er rock or fallen tree;
Where aspleniums, Aspleniums. There are numerous indigenous species of asplenium, the genus of fern commonly known as spleenwort. graceful, drooping,
Whisper breeze-stirred melody:
To sweet Nature’s charms addrest,
There my soul finds blessed rest.
Where mamaku ferns Mamaku ferns. Mamaku, or the black tree fern, grows as high as twenty metres with fronds as long as five metres in length. are spreading
Giant fronds to catch the light;
Where the cabbage Cabbage. Tī kōuka, also known as the cabbage tree, is a palm-like tree with narrow, pointed leaves. spearlets rustle,
All with odorous flowers bedight;
Where the tutu’s Tutu’s. Tutu is a highly poisonous shrub that bears dark-coloured berries. poisonous clusters
Droop in purple-berried mass;
Where the koromiko’s Koromiko’s. Koromiko is a common shrub that bears long flower spikes. lovely
Flower-spears kiss me as I pass;
Where the broad-leaved flax plants Flax plants. Harakeke, also known as flax, is an evergreen perennial that produces long flower spikes that are rich in nectar. cluster
With their honey-laden flowers;
And where laughing Flora peepeth
Ever from her sylvan bowers:
To sweet Nature’s charms addrest,
There my soul finds blessed rest.
Where the huge pohutakawa, Pohutakawa. Pōhutukawa is a coastal tree that grows in the North Island and bears bright red flowers in summer.
With its vivid, crimson crown,
From the cliffs, on ocean surges,
Casts its spreading shadows down;
Where innumerous lichens cluster
Many-hued, o’er every rock;
And mesembryanthemums Mesembryanthemums. Mesembryanthemum (ice plant) is a coastal plant introduced from South Africa. starry
With the lichens interlock;
Where the pendulous samphire Samphire. Likely a reference to rock samphire, a coastal plant introduced from the United Kingdom. swingeth
O’er the arch of ocean cave;
And where bright sea-flowers wave slowly
‘Neath the cool, translucent wave:
To sweet Nature’s charms addrest,
There my soul finds blessed rest.
In the solitude of Nature
Hymning voices meet my ear, Meet my ear. Sharpe had reportedly lost his hearing several years before the publication of this poem.
With a tender cadence thrilling
From all things I come anear:
There with friends I am surrounded;
There no loneliness I feel;
And to me her mystic wonders
Nature ever doth reveal;
And aneath some sylvan temple
Where man's foot hath seldom trod,
Read I, in the tome of Nature,
Wondrous things of Nature’s God:
To sweet Nature’s charms addrest,
There my soul finds blessed rest.
